title: Monday, 3rd December 2018

11:14 am

sprout So China moves up the value chain and the US moves down it. Well done Donald.
A. M. (@BE: unlike the groundhog, el presidente can unleash [further] destruction upon the planet)
BE11:16am

Which I'd put the same trust in as 90 day share sale lockups -- ie. it won't hold if either side chooses to break it so is effectively worthless.

hurdygurdy Morning peepsAnything on McColl's?
11:16 am
BE11:17am

Who can we quote here? Goldman? Goldman will do.

TonaldDrump once we get past the macro is there time for some grey on Kier please
BE11:18am

Actually, not Goldman. SocGen.

Tom Dalgleish Evening from Mandurah
BE11:18am

The US tariff increase from 10% to 25% on up to $200bn of Chinese goods will be delayed from Jan 1 pending discussions on trade. This two-month delay is good news to the extent that meaningful discussions can delay and possibly prevent a ratcheting up of trade tensions. However, we see no reasons to change our views. Trade policy should be a sustained issue for economies and financial markets.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

The US and China will commence trade discussions in mid-December in Washington. According to the US, discussions would be on forced technology transfers, intellectual property protections, non-tariff barriers and cyber security. These are issues for which the Chinese deny involvement. The wide divisions already imply lengthy discussions are needed. It remains uncertain how much progress can be made before March 1, the end of the 90-day reprieve.

BE11:18am

Postponement tells us that hard lines can soften, which is good news. The EU and US trade discussions have held off an escalation of trade protections, which offers a model. The US postponement of tariffs has a specific deadline and a goal regarding discussion points. These conditions are more rigid. The US can be softer or harder as March 1 approaches, and we do not know for certain what can satisfy US trade negotiators on progress. The US administration has both hard-line and soft-line views, each side at different times, appears to have an upper hand influencing President Trump. The considerable weight of issues needing to be resolved and the short postponement offered do not offer solid reasons for major view changes. Rather, a short postponement in view and slightly less conviction that tariffs will ever be increased is the take-away. After-all, there should be slightly more hope that ongoing discussions are enough to keep a tariff increase at bay. Regarding another set of US tariffs on $267bn of Chinese imports, we have not included that in our outlook. The Buenos Aires developments support keeping that view.

BE11:19am

And UBS.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

The Tump-Xi outcome was much better than we expected while Powell's comments
last week allayed fears amongst equity investors of overtightening. Oil is up on news of
a Saudi-Russia agreement. Trump, Xi and Powell delivered early Christmas presents,
and very underweight equity positioning that is 1.2stdev below avg can further fuel a
Santa Claus rally. We see risks to rallying beyond our 2875 year-end S&P target which
assumed a step up to the 25% rate but no further escalation/US-China talks.

BE11:19am

The S&P 500 NTM P/E has ranged from 15-17.2x since trade risks came to the fore in
Feb-Mar. The P/E is well below our model implied level, which would point to a forward
P/E around 17.2x, implying 3025 for the S&P 500 near-term. Using the implied derating
since Aug given the macro drivers, the implied P/E upside would be less (~1x)
and point to about 2950 for the S&P. Overall, the difference between our de-escalation
and escalation scenarios is about 600pts, suggesting trade can still move markets.

BE11:20am

We see the US-China ceasefire [...] as a very positive surprise for US equities. First and foremost, the agreement to enter into talks takes the downside scenario of additional tariffs on $267bn of goods and retaliation off the table near-term (7% downside case by our estimates). Second, postponing the step up to a 25% tariff rate removes a key overhang given the global economy was slowing and adding an additional stress was a risk; we estimated a 1.6% hit to S&P 500 EPS
from 25% tariffs in 2019, with a greater overhang to markets given FX risk (2-4%). Finally, the 90 day negotiating window likely means that the market largely prices out the incremental trade risks that were priced, at least until about mid Feb. How talks progress will drive how much risk would get priced in, or out (i.e. add/remove tariffs).

Tom Dalgleish What about some retrospective licence fees for Windows, 1990 onwards
11:20 am
BE11:20am

Implied rates volatility has fallen back to pre-Oct 3 levels on the back of Powell's
comments. Accordingly, with rates vol likely lower, we see affected risk premiums and
spreads narrowing. Surprisingly, despite fears of higher rates, the US 10y is well off the
highs and relative stock returns have been negatively correlated with respective rate
sensitivities since Sept as bond proxies have outperformed and financials performance
has been mixed. We see bond proxy sectors as likely to lag near-term.

Grouchmonkey Morning from deepest East Anglia
BE11:21am

And MOST.

BE11:21am

The pause of further tariff action is better than our baseline assumption of a 25% tariff on US$200bn of Chinese goods by Jan. 1, 2019. Trade negotiations in the next 90 days will be key to watch, and the road could remain bumpy toward a full resolution. We believe China needs to address key structural issues including IPR protections and industrial policy in future trade talks, which is consistent with China's domestic economic reform agenda. While we retain our view that China's GDP growth could decelerate to 6.3% in 2019 from 6.6% in 2018, an eventual de-escalation of trade tension would pose upside risk to our 2019 growth trajectory.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Equity strategy: Upgrade of MSCI China to OW versus MSCI EM - New MSCI China Base Case Target of 82 (+9%), Hang Seng 29,850 (+13%), HSCEI 12,100 (+14%) and CSI 300 of 3,650 (+15%): This G20 outcome represents a move some way (though not fully) towards the Bull Case scenario for US/China trade tensions that we outlined in our 26 Nov. year ahead outlook piece. Although we are entering a 3 month negotiation period, our own Base Case and that of the market we think was that the 1 Jan. 25% tariff would go ahead. We therefore raise our multiple assumption by 0.5x P/E points for the offshore China equities indices and by 0.3x P/E points for the onshore markets. This leads us to raise our Base Case MSCI China target from 79 to 82 (+9%), Hang Seng from 28,500 to 29,850 (+13%), HSCEI from 11,360 to 12,100 (+14%) and CSI 300 from 3,550 to 3,650 (+15%). Given there is less upside to our unchanged MSCI EM Base Case Target of 1050 (+6%) after recent gains, we raise MSCI China from EW to 100 bps OW. As we continue to be bullish our other key EM OWs of Brazil, India, Indonesia and Thailand, we fund this change of stance on MSCI China by increasing our UWs on Mexico and Australia to 250 bps each.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian "What about some retrospective licence fees for Windows" Maybe Windows should have been open source. It will have done more for poverty than anything Bill's foundation can do.

BE11:25am

2018 has been an exceptional year for the European autos sector with multiple variables that have
been dampening the sentiment and multiples overall on OEMs and suppliers which were not part of the
original chart book in January. To highlight a few: a) a badly managed WLTP transition in Europe across
some car makers; b) NAFTA trade renegotiation; c) trade war between US and China leading to exceptional
import tariffs for cars exported from North America into China hitting mainly BMW and Daimler; d) gradual
transition into new technologies to meet the 2020 EU CO2 emissions; e) gradual slowdown in the Chinese
auto market in H2FY18… to name a few variables.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @ A.M. - Quite true.
11:25 am
BE11:25am

Year end rally…We continue to stick to our view that demand in Europe is relatively healthy in FY18,
Brazilian and Russian car markets are rebounding from a low base, the North American car market is trending
sideways, and the Chinese car market is experiencing a technical slowdown in H2 FY18 post elimination of
purchase tax incentives over the past two years. As we travel into year end we see several catalysts: a)
confirmation from car makers (confirmed by our latest management meetings with Faurecia, VW amongst
other firms) that the year end transition after WLTP should be relatively uneventful, leaving WLTP behind us
the latest by Q1/Q2FY19; b) as reported across Bloomberg and Reuters a potential trade agreement between
US and China, which in our view would have two effects: 1. provide more stability to production schedules
globally; 2. potentially reduce the exceptionally high import tariffs implemented for cars exported from NA
into China benefiting mainly BMW and Daimler.

BE11:26am

We have been very vocal over the past weeks around several topics: a)
OW VW having delivered the trough in earnings already in Q3 plus we see the company meeting company
guidance for the year; b) Valeo is a stock we find oversold, where the company has the potential to improve
communication disclosure and show growth momentum over the coming quarters; c) PSA (OW/AFL) – our
all-weather OEM is in our view making progress to restructure Opel and has strong chances of surprising
investors with a quicker turnaround of the business than expected; d) within our tire maker coverage we would
favor Pirelli across the remaining coverage.

Dunelm Group PLC (DNLM:LSE): Last: 614.00, up 72 (+13.28%), High: 622.50, Low: 555.50, Volume: 431.85k
BE11:33am

(@ROTR: hi, can you keep in mind possible legal sensitivities and avoid writing anything I'll have to delete, ta.)

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Dunelm is a business built on strong foundations; a UK market leader with a 5% rent-to-sales ratio, 10%+ EBIT margins, 15% ROCE, 10% FCF yield and one of the lowest levels of operational gearing in the sector. Notwithstanding Brexit, we see clear catalysts for recovery in 2019 from a renewed focus on the core offer, improved brand awareness and an accelerating online performance as Dunelm fulfils its multi-channel potential. Shareholder returns will also benefit from the potential return of special dividends from next year. We upgrade Dunelm back to our Buy list and lift our target price to 750p.

BE11:34am

The most interesting bit to me was .........

BE11:35am

Dunelm has always been a top quartile retailer in our league tables. At its centre is a largely exclusive value offer that appeals to a broad church of customers, backed by a tight operational model that sees Dunelm’s rent bill run to an average of c£10/sq-ft, representing just c5% of sales. This combined focus on the offer and trading metrics flows through into strong EBIT margins, ROCE, cash flow and, ultimately, shareholder returns.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian I haven't got the waistline for TB. He doesn't do Santa Claus outfits.
BE11:43am

The rights issue comes as a surprise. It will clearly improve the balance sheet and reduce the financial risk of the group, better positioning the group in its markets. Management confirmed that the £250m raised will reduce average net debt by around £180m on an annualised basis, implying some leakage expected due to working capital movements. Management now expect a net cash position for FY2019 and are targeting an annualised net debt to EBITDA ratio of less than 1 times. The rights issue will accelerate debt reduction under the Future Proofing Kier programme by around two years. It is reassuring that the trading outlook remains as previously stated and in line with their expectations, but macro and political risks in the UK are clearly increasing, in relation to Brexit, and the outlook for 2019 remains exceptionally uncertain and a key risk for Kier Group. The actual macro outcome over the next 12-18 months will to a large extent determine whether leverage is now at the right level following the rights issue.

Tom Dalgleish That TB belt is still on sale worldwide 4 months later
BE11:43am

A back of the envelope calculation for FY2020 estimates suggests underlying EPS of around c.90p which would imply a DPS of c.36p, assuming 2.5 times cover. Using the current share price of c.580p, this would imply a FY2020E PE of c.6.5 times and dividend yield of c.6%.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

We expect net proceeds of £250m. However, we assume that £70m of that will be invested into the supply chain, but the dividend is lower. We therefore assume that FY net debt of £159m changes to FY net cash of £30m. We assume that average net debt falls by c.£90m ((£250m - £70m) x 6/12)) and reduce our FY average monthly net debt from £365m to £279m. Management indicates that average daily net debt for the year is c.£90m higher, or £369m. Management has historically guided to £20m to £40m of de-leveraging (before £20m of Future Proof Kier savings from FY 2020). Given the £70m investment in the supply chain, and ignoring the possible material inflow from a South East regional Healthcare contract, we now estimate an underlying increase in net debt of £30m to £50m. In addition, Kier remains committed to its £30m to £50m programme of disposals. In FY 2021, we reduce the previous estimate of average net debt of £250m by £250m, but add £70m, to reflect the changing procurement practices, and reflect the savings from the dividend and interest, giving £33m of average monthly net debt in FY2021, or £123m of average daily debt.

Blank canvas Opec?
BE11:47am

There was no change to underlying earnings guidance on Friday. The strategy is to pay off the RCF, rather than the more expensive, but longer duration PP loans, which come with redemption penalties. Management will leave the c.£45m average reverse factoring in place, on the basis that it is valued by suppliers. Assuming a reduction to average net debt of £90m in FY 2019 and £180m on FY 2020, and 2% cost of debt (3% coupon on the RCF less the 1% non-utilisation fee), we estimate a £1.8m interest saving in FY2019 and £3.6m saving in FY 2020. We assume a WANoS of 143m and 164m in FY 2019 and FY2020 including the bonus factor (see below). The level of dilution will of course depend on the price of the rights issue. We reduce our FY 2019 and FY 2020 FD EPS by 33% and 42% to 85p and 93p on a post right basis. We do not comment on valuation but note that the correct price to apply to the post rights EPS is the TERP.

We estimate top-line annual revenue growth of 52% based on CAGR from 2018-21 with product revenues of $238M in 2018 vs. $843M in 2021. We also assume SG&A cuts of 60-70%, as we assume that a potential acquirer might already have an oncology salesforce. We assume R&D cuts of 10-20% as well, since we think that a bigger biopharma company might also be able to run trials at a lower expense. We assume 20% tax rate and no tax synergies in this analysis.
